pullRequest.body:
Add some properties of the $X$-adic valuation on the rings $K[X]$ and $K[[X]]$ when $K$ is a field. It is an intermediate step towards the proof that the $X$-adic completion of $K(X)$ is isomorphic to $K((X))$.

Co-authored-by: María Inés de Frutos-Fernández @mariainesdff

:v: faenuccio can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9807612661/job/27081708761)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9807612661/job/27081708575)
Are you sure we want to choose a specific valuation for `K(X)`?

I imagine that your point is that in general $K[X]$ has many prime ideals and therefore many valuations, like the $(X-1)$-adic one, or the $f(X)$-adic one for every possible irreducible $f(X)$. Nevertheless, the field $K(X)$ has a "canonical" choice of variable, and we are incline to consider that the standard valuation on it is the $(X)$-adic one: if you want to put the $(X-1)$-adic, say, it seems more reasonable to perform a change of variables $(X-1)\mapsto Y$ and to use the standard valuation on $K(Y)$. So my answer is probably "I am not _sure_ but I think this is the right thing to do". Of course the other option would be to simply have a `def` here and go for localized instances, but I wonder whether it is worth it.
Maybe a scoped instance?

I wonder if this would really change anything. If all the material about this Valued instance is here, whenever it is needed one should `open scoped` and then the instance would fire as if it were a global one. I guess that the true question is whether we really want to avoid a `Valued` instance on polynomials/rational functions (and in this case we should simply let this be a `def` and promote it to an instance locally when needed), or if we're happy with the idea that $K(X)$ has many valuations but only one Valued structure.
@riccardobrasca @erdOne Have you more ideas on this `instance` problem?

What I was proposing is to keep it a def and add something like
```lean
scoped[foo] attribute [instance] blahblah
```
In this way `open scoped foo` makes it an instance. In particular one can use all the other results without having this instance. But I agree it's not very important.
I have no preference either way. I just wanted to make sure that this was a conscious choice, and I'll happily accept what you think is best.

OK, so here is my take on the situation: there are three ways to go:
1. Leave it a global instance as it is
2. Make it a `def valuedRatFunc` and go @riccardobrasca 's way by adding a `scoped [LaurentSeries] attribute [instance] valuedRatFunc` somewhere in the `LaurentSeries` namespace.
3. Make it a `def valuedRatFunc` and simply do an `attribute [local instance] valuedRatFunc` inside the file I am working on.

My first objection to @erdOne 's comment was that going for 2 is "almost equivalent"  to 1: if one would ever need to work with *any* Valued structure on LaurentSeries or Rational Functions, they would need to `open LaurentSeries` (to benefit of all the API) and the instance would fire, and one would have the same problems to declare a `Valued` structure using e.g. the $(X-1)$-adic valuation. In this sense, this is not much of an advantage. One solution would be to have a specific namespace (like $X$-adic valuation, or so) specifying that we are taking *this very* valuation into account: to me it looks a bit too much.

Solution 3 can work, with the obvious drawback that one needs to repeat this bit of code declaring the `local instance` each time one works with this.

If we stick to 1., one can add a bit of doc saying that if one wants to consider other valuations, this `Valued` instance must be locally disabled. This is what happens e.g. with the normed structure on the product of normed spaces if one does want an exotic norm on $\mathbb{R}^N$ which is not the $\ell^2$-norm.

As far as my project with Maria Ines is concerned (and this series of PR's) all options are not hard to implement, so I am happy to take any of the above options. I have a slight preference for 1. (plus the doc warning) but if you see otherwise, I'm all ears.

OK, let's go with 1.

bors d+

```suggestion
variable (K : Type*) [Field K]
```

```suggestion
  asIdeal := Ideal.span {X}
```
Untested, but if it works you can do the same everywhere else.
It works

```suggestion
    (idealX K).valuation (RatFunc.X : RatFunc K) = Multiplicative.ofAdd -1 := by
```
Untested.
Nope...

```suggestion
end Polynomial

namespace RatFunc
```
Do we really need to open `Classical`?
We don't, removed.

```suggestion
theorem intValuation_apply {R : Type *} [CommRing R] [IsDedekindDomain R] {r : R}
```
I guess there already is an `R` in scope.
Good catch.

```suggestion
    (idealX K).intValuation P = (idealX K).intValuation (↑P : K⟦X⟧) := by
```
No, unfortunately this does not work; Lean thinks the first is the ideal in the power series and automatically coerces `P` there.

```suggestion
    Multiset.count PowerSeries.X (normalizedFactors (P : k⟦X⟧)) =
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: add properties of the X-adic valuation on `PowerSeries K`
